column4: Anyone know why dd would be copying at a rate of 2.8 MB/s between two 3gb/s sata drives? :(
are they internal or usb?
both internal, but the source is a partition
I'm beginning to think the drive has gone bad
are you running dd on a drive and storing the image on the other?
I ran this command dd if=/dev/sda1 of=/dev/sdb1
so your imaging a drive that will slow things down a bit
I really didn't want an image, but the exact file structure, because I'm copying my broken windows partition on to another drive
should I restart the process differently, because this is painfully slow
imaging or a bit by bit copy will be slow, especially if the disk is damaged, ie bad sectors etc
i image drives a fare amount and depending on size it can take most of the day or longer
will it matter that the source partition is larger than the destination, but the amount of data on the source is less than the destination partition
I don't want to get to the end and see an error
i am guessing its not for forensics, what exactly are you trying to do?
I have a 50GB drive, with a 350GB windows(ntfs) partition and a 100GB ubuntu partition.  Windows went bad, so I booted into ubuntu to backup the windows partition to another 250GB drive I have
are you going to reinstall windows?
yes
if ubuntu can read the drive then copy the files you need to keep, only us dd if there is problems reading the drive
ok thanks
dd images or copies everything that can be read and attempts to recreate on the destination
also keep in mind linux ignores windows permissions etc and will add the permissions of the user account copying and same when writing back to windows although easier to manipulate on ntfs
